title: The Passover and the Cloud
shortSummary: Numbers chapter 9 recounts the observance of the Passover in the wilderness and addresses exceptions for those who were ceremonially unclean or traveling. It also describes the divine guidance of Israel through the cloud over the tabernacle, which directed their journeys and encampments. This chapter highlights God's provision for obedience and His presence leading His people.
timeline: c. 1445 BC - The second year after the Exodus, during Israel's wilderness journey at Mount Sinai

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's commands and instructs the people regarding the Passover and their journey.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who, along with Moses, hears the concerns of the men defiled by a dead body and participates in leading Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Certain Men Defiled by a Dead Body
keyCharacters.description: Individuals who were ceremonially unclean and unable to keep the Passover at the appointed time, seeking God's provision.

definitions.definition: A sacred Jewish feast commemorating God's deliverance of Israel from Egyptian bondage by sparing the firstborn of those marked by the blood of the lamb.
Ceremonially unclean, especially by contact with a dead body, which temporarily disqualified one from participating in holy rites.
The portable sanctuary where God's presence dwelt among Israel during their wilderness journey.
The visible manifestation of God's presence that covered the tabernacle by day and guided Israel's movements.

outline.heading: Command to Keep the Passover
outline.description: God instructs Moses to have Israel observe the Passover in the wilderness on the fourteenth day of the first month, and the people obey exactly as commanded, emphasizing the importance of covenant remembrance.

outline.heading: Provision for the Unclean and Travelers
outline.description: Men who were ceremonially unclean due to contact with a dead body question Moses and Aaron about missing the Passover; God provides a second opportunity to observe it in the second month, showing His mercy and allowance for circumstances.

outline.heading: Inclusion of the Stranger
outline.description: God extends the Passover ordinance to any foreigner residing among Israel, demonstrating the inclusive nature of God's covenant community when they follow His statutes.

outline.heading: The Cloud Over the Tabernacle
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a detailed description of the cloud covering the tabernacle by day and fire by night, which directed Israel’s movements, underscoring God's continual presence and sovereign guidance.

application: Trust in God's timing and provision even when circumstances prevent you from fulfilling spiritual duties as planned.
Obedience to God's commands is essential; neglecting His appointed times and ordinances carries serious consequences.
Recognize and honor God's presence in your life as a guide and protector, just as Israel followed the cloud.
Extend grace and inclusion to others who seek to follow God’s ways, regardless of their background.

keyVerses.text: Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, If any man of you or of your posterity shall be unclean by reason of a dead body, or be in a journey afar off, yet he shall keep the passover unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's mercy and provision for those unable to keep the Passover at the appointed time, showing His understanding of human limitations.

keyVerses.text: And if a stranger shall sojourn among you, and will keep the passover unto the LORD; according to the ordinance of the passover, and according to the manner thereof, so shall he do: ye shall have one ordinance, both for the stranger, and for him that was born in the land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the inclusiveness of God's covenant community, welcoming foreigners who faithfully observe His commands.

keyVerses.text: At the commandment of the LORD they rested in the tents, and at the commandment of the LORD they journeyed: they kept the charge of the LORD, at the commandment of the LORD by the hand of Moses.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Israel's obedience to God's guidance through Moses, demonstrating the importance of following divine direction in all aspects of life.
